description: From Middle English among, amang, amonge, amange, from Old English amang, onġemang, equivalent to a- +‎ mong (“crowd; group; throng”). Compare dialectal German mang, Saterland Frisian monk, monken (“among”).
The raising of /ɔ/ ( → /ɒ/) to /u/ ( → /ʌ/) is regular between /m/ and /ŋ/; compare monger, mongrel.

entries.meaning: Denotes a mingling or intermixing with distinct or separable objects. (See Usage Note at amidst.)
examples: How can you speak with authority about their customs when you have never lived among them?

entries.meaning: Denotes a belonging of a person or a thing to a group.
examples: He is among the few who completely understand the subject.

entries.meaning: Denotes a sharing of a common feature in a group.
examples: Lactose intolerance is common among people of Asian heritage.
